arm_group.description: Rapid Diagnostic Test for malaria to direct antimalarial dispensing decisions in Chemical Shops
Chemical sellers dispense antimalarials as per their own decisions without the benefit of test results

brief_summary.textblock:
This study aims to test directly by means of a cluster randomized controlled trial, the
      impact of the introduction of RDTs for malaria on dispensing behaviour of chemical sellers,
      the main non-formal outlet for drugs locally, at community level.

clinical_study.brief_title: The Role of Rapid Diagnostic Tests for Malaria for Targeting of ACTs at Community Level

detailed_description.textblock:
In many settings the majority of people with malaria particularly the poorest do not access
      formal care but access anti-malarials at the informal community level. ACTs were previously
      unaffordable to this group but this should change with the introduction of the AMFm. To
      avoid missing alternative causes of illness, reduce costs and delay the spread of resistance
      to ACTs, they need to be targeted at those who really need them. Studies in formal
      healthcare settings in Ghana have shown that where microscopy is not available, the impact
      of Rapid Diagnostic Tests (RDTs) can be substantial. RDTs are relatively simple to use,
      requiring fairly minimal training to master the mechanics of test preparation and
      interpretation Whether to deploy RDTs as part of AMFm is unclear at this time.Even in the
      absence of AMFm the question about how best to target antimalarials in the community is an
      important one, and will get more so as malaria incidence in many countries decreases, making
      presumptive treatment of all febrile illness as malaria increasingly ineffective. Locally
      chemical sellers are the closest equivalent as they provide the majority of treatments,
      especially for the poorest.

      It is difficult to predict whether RDTs would make chemical sellers more commonly accessed
      (because patients prefer a diagnosis) , or less accessed (patients do not like having choice
      restricted/do not want a blood test etc). Studies in other settings suggest interventions to
      improve diagnosis by shop-keepers can be effective and cost-effective .

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Patients reporting to chemical seller with complaint of fever or who request for an
             anti-malarial drug

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Clients providing a prescription from a health facility

          -  Clients with signs of severe disease who will be referred onward

intervention.description: Rapid Diagnostic Test for Malaria carried out to direct antimalarial dispensing. No antimalarials for negative tests, antimalarials for positive tests

facility.name: Dodowa Health Research Centre, Ghana Health Service

clinical_study.official_title: The Role of Rapid Diagnostic Tests for Malaria for Targeting of ACTs at Community Level: a Cluster Randomized Trial

overall_official.affiliation: London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine

authority: United Kingdom: London School of Hygiene & Tropical Medicine

primary_outcome.description: Out of all clients who test negative when their blood slides are read by two independent expert microscopists, how many received an antimalarial treatment from the Licensed Chemical Seller
primary_outcome.measure: The proportion of clients negative for malaria by double read research blood slide who received an anti-malarial in both arms
primary_outcome.time_frame: Until the estimated sample size is obtained or up to 2 yrs whichever comes first

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Out of all clients who test negative by RDT, number who receive an antimalarial
secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of  mRDT -ve clients who received an anti-malarial in the RDT arm
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Until the estimated sample size is obtained or up to 2 years, whichever comes first

secondary_outcome.description: The number of clients who agree to be tested with an RDT Out of all clients who meet inclusion criteria
secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of clients tested using a Rapid Diagnostic Test
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Until the estimated sample size is obtained or up to 2 years, whichever comes first

secondary_outcome.description: The number of clients in the intervention and control arms who receive an antibiotic out of the total number of clients recruited into each arm
secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of clients in each arm receiving an antibiotic
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Until the estimated sample size is obtained or up to 2 years, whichever comes first

secondary_outcome.description: The number of clients who receive additional or alternative treatments in the intervention and control arms out of the total number recruited into both arms
secondary_outcome.measure: Proportion of clients receiving addittional or alternative treatments to antimalarial and which these are
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Until the estimated sample size is obtained or up to 2 years, whichever comes first

collaborator.agency: London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Safety/Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Open Label, Primary Purpose: Diagnostic
